9.12.120 Regulations not applicable when.
9.12.010 Definitions. "Explosive" or "explosives", whenever used in this chapter means and includes any chemical compound or chemical mixture that contains any oxidizing or combustible units or other ingredients in such proportion, quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, friction, concussion, percussion, or detonation of any part of the compound or mixture may cause such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructive effects on contiguous objects or of destroying life or limb. (Ord. 269 '1, 1949).
9.12.020 Permit required. lt is unlawful to keep or store, or permit to be kept or stored, used or transported, any explosives within the city without first complying with the laws of the state and obtaining a permit therefor from the city clerk, and without complying with all of the provisions of this chapter relating to explosives and the handling, storage, use, and transportation thereof. (Ord. 269 '2, 1949).
9.12.030 Storage outside of city. Every person, firm or corporation in the city engaged in the business of handling, storing, using, or transporting explosives shall establish one central loading station situated outside the city, where delivery shall be made to customers. (Ord. 269 '3, 1949).
9.12.040 Application for permit. No person shall handle, store, use, or transport explosives within the city without first obtaining a permit so to do. At the time this permit is applied for they shall furnish the city clerk with accurate information as to the kind and quantity of explosives to be handled, stored, used, or transported, and the disposition to be made of them; the vehicle or conveyance in which they are to be
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 3
transported; the names and number of persons in charge; and the route or routes to be traveled; the length of time for which the permit is desired; the class of magazine in which the explosives are to be kept or stored; and such other reasonable information as may be desired by the city clerk, all of which shall be incorporated in the permit. This section shall not apply to railroads or other transportation companies that are hauling explosives through Ephrata or are delivering them as articles of commerce to consignees within the city. (Ord. 269 '4, 1949).
9.12.050 Permit time period, revocation. Permits to handle, store, use, or transport explosives within the city shall not be issued for a longer period than thirty days, and the city clerk is authorized to revoke any such permit upon violation by the holder thereof of any of the provisions hereof relating to the handling, storing, use, or transporting of explosives. (Ord. 269 '5, 1949).
9.12.060 Bond. No permit for keeping, storing, use, handling, or transportation of explosives within the city shall be issued except as herein otherwise provided, until the applicant therefor shall have furnished a good and sufficient surety bond in such amount as may be determined by the city council, approved by the mayor, and approved as to form by the city attorney, and conditioned:
(1) That the applicant will abide by the terms and conditions of this chapter and the laws of the state relating to the handling, keeping, storing, use, and transportation of explosives, and will save harmless and indemnify the city for any and all loss or damage of any kind or character which may be suffered by the city by reason of or resulting from the keeping, storing, use, handling, or transportation of the explosives;
(2) To save harmless and indemnify the city from any and all loss, damage, actions, and claims of any kind or character which may accrue to or be suffered by any person by reason of or resulting from the keeping, storing, use, handling, or transportation of the explosives;
(3) To save harmless and indemnify any and all persons for any and all loss or damage of any kind or character which may be suffered by them by reason of or resulting from the keeping, storing, use, handling, or transportation of the explosives. The obligations under the bond shall not be terminated before sixty days from the date of written notice to the city clerk that the keeping, storing, use, handling, or transportation of the explosives has been terminated. (Ord. 269 '6, 1949).
9.12.070 Public officers need not furnish bond. Public officials and employees using, keeping, storing, handling, or transporting explosives in connection with public work shall not be required to furnish the bond herein above specified, but shall be subject to all other provisions relating to explosives. (Ord. 269 '7, 1949).
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 4
9.12.080 Qualifications of persons handling. No permit shall be issued for the handling, storing, use or transportation of explosives within the city unless it is shown to the satisfaction of the city clerk that the person who is to handle, keep, store, use, or transport the explosives is over the age of twenty-one years, able to speak, read, and write the English language, possessed of good sight and hearing, good habits, intelligence, reliability and judgment, has had no less than two years' experience in the work, and shall be familiar with the necessary precautions to be taken incident to the service to be performed by him. The habits, appearance, and fitness of such persons shall be certified to by someone who has known the applicant for a period of at least one year and whose judgment is considered competent and reliable to the city clerk. (Ord. 269 '8, 1949).
9.12.090 Blasting. All permits for blasting within the city shall limit the time for blasting within the hours from eight a.m. to five p.m., unless it is shown to the satisfaction of the city clerk that blasting at other times during the day would be just as safe. Before any explosives are used, or a blast is set off, the persons using the explosives shall take every precaution to clear all people from the area where the explosives are being used, and to warn all persons living near the area where the explosives are being used, and shall take all other proper steps to protect persons and their property from any possible harm which may occur from the use of explosives. (Ord. 269 '9, 1949).
9.12.100 Miscellaneous provisions. Whenever explosives are handled, stored, used, or transported within the city limits, the following miscellaneous provisions, in addition to the provisions contained elsewhere in this chapter and the laws of the state, shall apply:
(1) All explosives coming within the city shall be of known quality and of standard manufacture. Such explosives shall be packed and marked in compliance with the Interstate Commerce Commission's regulations governing the transportation of explosives, as formulated and published from time to time;
(2) All explosives shall be kept apart and away from fire or artificial light, other than electric flashlight or electric lantern, and no person shall have, drop, throw, or leave any fire, lighted match, cigar, cigarette, or pipe ashes within fifty feet of any magazine or receptacle containing explosives;
(3) Explosives shall not be exposed to the weather or to the direct rays of the sun, nor shall any explosive or any grains or particles thereof be left or permitted to remain on the outside of or about the containers in which they are encased or enclosed;
(4) If any explosive shall deteriorate so as to be in a dangerous condition, or if any nitroglycerine shall leak out of any explosive, the person to whom the permit for
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 5
the handling, storing, using, or transporting of the explosive has been issued shall immediately notify the fire marshal and shall cause the explosive to be disposed of in such manner as the fire marshal may require;
(5) No person shall discharge any firearm at or in the neighborhood of explosives. (Ord. 269 '10, 1949).
9.12.110 Types prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to handle, store, use, or transport within the city any of the following named explosives:
(1) Liquid nitroglycerine;
(2) Any explosive containing over sixty percent of nitroglycerine, except gelatine dynamite;
(3) Gelatine dynamite equal in strength to dynamite containing more than seventy-five percent nitroglycerine;
(4) Any explosive having a nonretentive absorbent or one that permits leakage of nitroglycerine under any condition liable to exist during the handling, storage or transportation of the same;
(5) Nitrocellulose in a dry condition in quantity greater than ten pounds in one exterior package;
(6) Fulminate or mercury in bulk in a dry condition, and fulminate or any other metal in any condition except as a component of manufactured articles not prohibited within the city;
(7) Any explosive containing an ammonium salt and a chlorate. (Ord. 269 '11, 1949).
9.12.120 Regulations not applicable when. None of the requirements hereof relating to the handling, storage, use, and transportation of explosives shall apply:
(1) To gunpowder in closed metal receptacles of a capacity not exceeding one pound each, of a total quantity not exceeding fifty pounds, when plainly marked "gun powder" and when kept at all times in view near the entrance to the premises;
(2) To munitions of war when the same are under the direct control and jurisdiction of the Army and Navy of the United States, or to military supplies of the state of Washington under the direct control and jurisdiction of the National Guard of the state of Washington, where the rules and practices of the federal government and/or the state of Washington would be affected adversely thereby;
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 6
(3) To the fire or police department in the proper performance of their duties;
(4) To gasoline, kerosene, fuel oil, and other petroleum products not usually classed as explosives. (Ord. 269 '12, 1949).
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 7
Chapter 9.18
FIREWORKS REGULATIONS
Sections:
9.18.010 Scope. This ordinance applies to the manufacture, possession, storage, sale, transportation and use of fireworks. This ordinance does not prohibit the following:
(1) The use of any device allowed by state law or regulation except where such use is specifically prohibited herein;
(2) The use of any blank cartridges for use in athletics or sports events;
(3) The use of fireworks by military operations for the purpose of bona fide military exercises, demonstrations or ceremonials;
9.18.020 Definitions.
(1) "Fireworks" means any composition or device, in a finished state, containing any combustible or explosive substance for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration, or detonation, and classified as common or special fireworks.
(2) "Special Fireworks" means any fireworks designed primarily for exhibition display by producing visible or audible effects as defined by WAC 212-17-035 (2)-(7) as written now or hereafter amended.
(3) "Common Fireworks" means any fireworks designed primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustions defined by WAC 212-17-035 (1) (a)-(g) as written now or hereafter amended
(4) "Special Effects" has the meaning provided by RCW 70.77.146.
(5) "Agricultural and Wildlife Fireworks" has the meaning provided by RCW 70.77.141.
(6) "Fire nuisance" has the meaning provided by RCW 70.77.165.
(7) "Fire Chief" means the chief of the City of Ephrata's Fire Department and/or his designee who shall be the local fire official for purposes of RCW Chapter 70.77.
(8) “Aerial Devices” means those listed in WAC 212-17-035 (2)
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 8
paragraphs (a) through (c), and (3) combination items, as written now or hereafter amended.
(9) “Public Display” means an entertainment event where the general public is, or could be, admitted or allowed to view the display or discharge of fireworks as defined by RCW 70.77.160 as written now or hereafter amended. (Ord 14-04, 2014)
9.18.030 Acts Prohibited Without a Permit. No person shall do any of the following acts within the City without having first obtained and having in full force and effect a valid permit issued by the City to do so:
(1) Manufacture, import, possess, or sell, at wholesale or retail, any class or kind of fireworks, for any use whatsoever, excluding possession of Common Fireworks lawfully purchased at retail.
(2) Discharge or ignite any class or kind of fireworks at any place, excluding common fireworks lawfully purchased at retail at such places and times as permitted by this Chapter.
(3) Make a public display of any class or kind of fireworks.
(4) Transport any class or kind of fireworks, except as follows:
(a) as a public carrier delivering to a licensee; or,
(b) transportation of common fireworks in a private passenger vehicle during the legal sales period established in this Chapter.
(5) Store fireworks of any class or kind in any amount exceeding ten (10) pounds aggregate weight.
(6) Discharge special fireworks.
(7) Use or discharge fireworks of any class or kind inside a structure.
(8) Use or discharge fireworks of any class or kind for ceremonial purposes; provided that there shall be no fee for such permit.
(Ord 14-04, 2014)
9.18.040 Application for Permit.
1. Any person desiring to do any act set forth in Section 9.18.030 shall first make written application for a permit to the City of Ephrata. The application for a permit shall be signed by the applicant. If the application is made by a partnership, it shall be signed by each partner of the partnership, and if the application is made by a corporation, it shall be signed by an officer of the corporation and bear the seal of the corporation.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 9
The application shall be in such form as the City of Ephrata shall require and shall include, as a minimum, the following information:
(a) The true name, address and telephone number of the applicant;
(b) A statement by the applicant that he or she is over the age of eighteen (18) years of age;
(c) A statement as to whether the applicant possesses a license issued by the State Fire Marshal to do the act for which the permit is sought, and the current status of said license;
(d) The proposed location at which the applicant intends to perform the act for which the permit is sought; and
(e) Such other information as the City of Ephrata may require in order to make any investigation or report required by this chapter.
2. All applications for permits pursuant hereto shall be accompanied by a non-refundable permit fee, to cover the administrative costs for processing and inspection, in such amount as shall be set by the City Council by resolution, not to exceed One Hundred Dollars ($100.00).
3. All applications for permits pursuant hereto other than public display permits shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance as evidence that the applicant carries a comprehensive general liability insurance policy written on an "occurrence basis" and not a "claims made basis" with minimum coverage of One Million Dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury liability for each person and event and not less than One Million Dollars ($1,000,000.00) for property damage liability for each event. Such general liability policy shall name the City of Ephrata as a additional insured, must be in full force and effect for the duration of the permit, and shall include a provision prohibiting cancellation of said policy without thirty (30) days written notice to the City. Said policy and certificate shall be in a form approved by the City Attorney.
4. Applications for public display of fireworks shall be made in writing at least ten (10) days in advance of the proposed display.
5. Except as provided by RCW 70.77.355, all applications for a permit for a public display of fireworks shall be accompanied by a bond or certificate of insurance meeting the requirements of RCW 70.77.285 and 70.77.295, as now stated or hereafter amended.
(Ord 14-04, 2014)
9.18.050 Application for Seller's Permit - Conditions for Issuance. Applications for seller's permits shall be made to the Fire Chief annually on or after January 1st of the year for which the permit is issued and the filing period shall close on June 1st of such year unless extended by action of the City
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 10
Council. Applications shall be signed before a notary public by the retail seller if an individual, or by the duly authorized officer, if an association or corporation. It is unlawful for a fireworks manufacturer, wholesaler or supplier to make application for or to obtain a retail sales permit on behalf of any retailer. Seller's permits shall be issued only to applicants meeting the following conditions:
(1) The retailer or person in charge and responsible for the retail operation shall be over twenty-one (21) years of age, of good moral character and have demonstrated responsibility.
(2) The applicant shall have a valid and current license issued by the Washington State Fire Marshal pursuant to RCW Chapter 70.77 authorizing the holder thereto to engage in the retail sale of fireworks.
(3) The applicant shall own or have the right to possess a temporary fireworks stand complying with the requirements of this Chapter.
(4) The permit holder's location or place of business shall be only in those areas or zones within the City wherein retail sales are authorized under applicable zoning law.
(5) The applicant must possess and have in full force and effect a valid "Transient Merchants and Vendors" business license issued by the City of Ephrata pursuant to Ephrata Municipal Code (EMC) chapter 5.40. The transient merchants/vendors business license fee for the operation of each business selling fireworks lawfully within the city shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) per stand except for those businesses which are operated by non-profit companies, associations, corporations or co-partnerships which shall pay a business license fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per stand.
(6) The applicant shall be required to report to the State Department of Revenue the City's sales tax number in conjunction with payment of any sales taxes due from retail sales originating in the City.
(Ord 14-04, 2014)
9.18.060 Investigation, Report on Permit Application. It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to make an investigation and prepare a report of his findings and conclusions for or against the issuance of the permit, together with his reasons therefor. In the case of an application for a permit for a public
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 11
display of fireworks, the Fire Chief shall, in addition to any other investigation, make an investigation as to whether such display as proposed will be of such character and will be so located that it may be hazardous to property or dangerous to any person.
9.18.070 City Council May Grant or Deny Permit - Conditions. The City Council shall have the power to grant or deny any application for a permit, or to subject the same to reasonable conditions, if any, as it shall prescribe. The City Council shall deny any application which contains material misrepresentation or if it finds that the public health, safety, or welfare would be adversely affected by granting the permit. Considerations shall include:
(1) Whether the activity and structure housing the activity, if any, will be in compliance with all applicable zoning, building, fire and other ordinances and regulations.
(2) Danger of fire or explosion associated with the place designated in the application.
(3) Adequacy of fire extinguishing equipment to be kept available at such place.
(4) Experience and training of the applicant relevant to safety of the activity.
(5) Compatibility of use with surrounding land uses, particularly such uses as hospitals, retirement centers, nursing homes, day-care facilities, and other uses which might be disrupted by the activity.
(6) Compliance with the provisions of this chapter. When possible, conditions shall be placed upon issuance of the permit as needed to eliminate dangers or incompatibility with other uses which would otherwise require denial of the permit.
9.18.080 License Required Prior to Issuance of Permit. No permit shall be issued unless the person applying therefor shall first have obtained and have in full force and effect a valid license issued by the State Fire Marshal, pursuant to RCW Chapter 70.77, to do the particular act or acts for which the permit is sought.
9.18.090 Public Display Permit - Granted for Exclusive Purpose - Nontransferable. If a permit for the public display of fireworks is granted, the sale, possession and use of fireworks for the public display is lawful for that purpose only. No such permit shall be transferable.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 12
9.18.100 Supervision of Public Display. Every public display of fireworks shall be handled or supervised by a pyrotechnic operator approved by the Fire Chief and licensed by the State Fire Marshal.
9.18.110 Permit - Authorized Activities of Employees. The authorization to engage in the particular act or acts as conferred by a permit to a person shall extend to the employees of such person, provided all such employees are eighteen (18) years of age or older, unless a higher age requirement is imposed upon the licensee by this chapter in which case such requirement shall apply to employees, and provided that section 9.18.100 governing public displays shall be complied with.
9.18.120 Revocation or Suspension of Permit.
(1) Authority. The Fire Chief may at any time suspend or revoke any permit issued under the provisions of this chapter, if the permittee has:
(a) Violated any of the provisions of this chapter or any permit condition imposed by the City Council, or if such a violation has been committed by any of his servants, agents or employees;
(b) Violated any provision of RCW 70.77;
(c) Made any false statement or misrepresentation of fact in connection with obtaining the permit;
(d) Failed to obtain, or has had suspended or revoked, any license required by RCW Chapter 70.77 or this Chapter; or
(e) Had any insurance coverage required by this Chapter canceled, revoked or lapsed;
Or if circumstances affecting public safety are discovered which, if known at the time of application for the permit, would have justified denial of the application.
(2) Effective Date of Revocation. When the Fire Chief determines that there is cause for revoking or suspending any permit issued pursuant to this Chapter, the Fire Chief shall notify the person holding such permit in writing of such determination. The notice shall specify the grounds for the suspension or revocation of the permit. The suspension or revocation shall become effective after the permittee has been given reasonable opportunity to respond to the notice and the Fire Chief has considered whether such response merits withdrawal of his determination. The opportunity to respond may be informal. A formal hearing prior to suspension or revocation is not required. When the Fire Chief determines that a
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 13
significant, imminent threat to public safety is caused by continued operation under the permit and that the circumstances do not allow delay, the permit may be immediately suspended on a temporary opportunity to respond as set forth above. Permanent revocation of a permit shall not be implemented prior to giving the permittee an opportunity to be heard in opposition to such action.
(3) Appeal. The decision of the Fire Chief with respect to the revocation or suspension of any permit issued under this Chapter shall be appealable to the City Council. A written notice of appeal stating specifically the errors which are claimed to justify overturning the action of the Fire Chief shall be filed with the City Clerk. The appeal shall be considered at the next regular meeting following filing of the notice of appeal unless the permittee consents to a later hearing. Any appeal or other request for judicial review of the decision of the City Council not filed with the Grant County Superior Court and served on the City within ten (10) days of the Council's decision shall be barred.
(4) In the event of any conflict between this section and section 9.18.190 governing standards for public fireworks displays, said section shall control over the provisions of this section.
9.18.130 Unlawful Fireworks Sales.
(1) It is unlawful for any person to sell, transfer, or agree to sell or transfer any fireworks, other than common fireworks, to any person who is not a fireworks licensee as provided for by RCW Chapter 70.77 and this Chapter.
(2) It is unlawful for any person to sell or transfer any common fireworks to a consumer or other user other than at the place of business of a retail seller of fireworks for which a license pursuant to RCW Chapter 70.77 and a permit pursuant to this Chapter have been issued.
9.18.140 Restriction Upon Sale of Fireworks Within City. It shall be unlawful to offer for sale at retail, or to engage in the retail sale of any of the following fireworks, notwithstanding the inclusion of any of such fireworks within the definition of "common fireworks" as defined by RCW Chapter 70.77 and regulations issued by the State Fire Marshal:
Those listed in WAC 212-17-035(2) Aerial Device paragraphs (a) through (c) and in WAC 212-17-035(3) (as written now or hereafter amended) Combination items and aerial (flying) bees. It shall further be unlawful to offer for sale at retail or to engage in the retail sale of any common fireworks between the hours of eleven o'clock pm and nine o'clock am. No common fireworks shall be sold except from twelve o'clock noon on
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 14
June 28th to 11 o'clock pm on July 4th of each year, and from twelve o’clock noon on December 29th to 11 o’clock p.m. on December 31st of each year. (Ord 14-04, 2014; Ord 15-14, 2015)
9.18.150 Fireworks Sales - Location.
(1) Fireworks which may be lawfully sold pursuant to this chapter shall be sold at retail only from temporary fireworks stands, the construction and location of which have been approved as provided in this section.
(2) All fireworks stands shall be erected in a stable and safe manner and must be approved by the Fire Chief and the City Code Compliance Officer prior to use.
(3) Location – Location of retail fireworks stand shall comply with WAC 212-17-21509, as written now or hereafter amended.
(4) All weeds, grass and combustible material shall be cleared from the location of the temporary fireworks stand and the surrounding area a distance of not less than twenty feet, measured from the exterior walls on each side of the temporary fireworks stand.
(5) Each fireworks stand shall have a person who is eighteen years or older in attendance at all times the stand is stocked. No person under sixteen years of age shall be permitted to sell fireworks or to remain within a fireworks stand while open to the public. Stock from the stand shall not be removed and stored in any other building during the sales period without the express approval of the Fire Chief.
(6) Each fireworks stand shall have provisions for sufficient off-street parking, at least fifteen spaces, to avoid impeding a continuous flow of traffic at entrances and exits from the premises. None of the required off street parking shall be located closer than twenty feet to any fireworks stand.
(7) No motor vehicles shall be permitted within 20 feet of any fireworks stand at any time the stand is stocked, except when delivering, loading, or unloading fireworks.
(8) There must be posted on the exterior of all walls of the temporary fireworks stand a complete list of those areas where the discharge or ignition of fireworks are prohibited within the City of Ephrata.
(9) No smoking shall be permitted in or near a temporary fireworks stand for a distance of not less than twenty feet measured for the exterior walls of the temporary fireworks stand.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 15
(10) All unsold stock and accompanying litter shall be removed from the fireworks stand and surrounding area by twelve noon on the 7th day of July of each year.
(11) No person shall discharge any fireworks within 100 feet of the exterior walls of the temporary fireworks stand and signs stating "No discharge of fireworks within 100 feet" shall be posted on the exterior of all walls of the temporary fireworks stand.
(12) All heating units shall be listed by a recognized testing laboratory and shall be used in accordance with the listing. Heating sources shall have “tip-over” and temperature overheat protection. All heating devices shall have sealed type elements (i.e., oil filled or water filled radiator type). Open flame heating devices are prohibited.
(13) Generators which use combustible fuel and which are at least twenty feet from the retail fireworks stand or the temporary fireworks storage structure shall be allowed. Generator fuel shall be limited to not more than five gallons and stored at least twenty feet from all stands.
(14) Customers shall not be permitted within a fireworks stand.
(15) No fireworks shall be stored outside the fireworks stand in any vehicle, trailer, or camper. Overnight sleeping in a stand is prohibited. No trailer or camper may be permitted within twenty feet of any fireworks stand.
(Ord 14-04, 2014)
9.18.160 Fireworks Sales - Age Limitation. Sales of fireworks shall be prohibited to anyone under the age of sixteen years. Identification documenting age shall be shown upon request.
9.18.170 Discharge of Fireworks Prohibited at Certain Locations. No fireworks of any type or classification shall be discharged or ignited within the City at any of the following locations:
(1) In or upon any public park or other publicly owned property, not including publicly owned streets and sidewalks.
(2) Within 300 feet of any hospital, nursing home, retirement center, public library, church, synagogue or other place of worship.
(3) Within, or closer than 100 feet to any stand or field of dry grass or other dry plant material, whether or not designated as a hazardous fire area.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 16
(4) Within 200 feet of any gasoline station, tank or premises where flammable liquids or gases are used or stored for dispensing where the volume stored is in excess of 500 gallons.
(5) Within 100 feet of any hotel, motel or "bed and breakfast" lodging and boarding facility.
9.18.180 Dates and Times that Use of Fireworks is Permitted. No common fireworks shall be discharged or ignited except between the following hours and dates:
June 28 12:00 noon to 11:00 pm
June 29-July 3 9:00 am to 11:00 pm
July 4 9:00 am to 12:30 am
December 31 9:00 pm to 12:15 am
(Ord 14-04, 2014; Ord 15-14, 2015)
9.18.190 Standards for Public Fireworks Displays. No public fireworks display may be conducted without having first obtained and having in full force and effect a permit issued by the City. All public fireworks displays shall conform to the following standards and conditions, in addition to all applicable standards and conditions prescribed by State law:
1. A scaled drawing shall be submitted to the City of Ephrata showing a plan view of the fireworks discharge site and the surrounding area within a five-hundred-foot radius. The drawing shall include all structures, fences, barricades, streets, fields, streams, and any other significant factors that may be subjected to ignition or that may inhibit fire-fighting capabilities.
2. The City of Ephrata may require a City of Ephrata Fire Department fire-fighting apparatus and a minimum of two trained Department fire-fighters shall be on-site thirty minutes prior to and after the shooting of the event. The Fire Department shall receive a minimum compensation as per the Washington State Chiefs Association’s fee schedule.
3. All compensation for Fire Department apparatus will be as per the Washington State Chiefs Association's fee schedule and shall be revenue to the Fire Department's general fund.
4. All combustible debris and trash shall be removed from the area of discharge and ignition for a distance of 500 feet in all directions.
5. All unfired or "dud" fireworks shall be disposed of in a safe manner.
6. A minimum of two 2A-rated pressurized water fire extinguishers shall be
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 17
required to be at the fireworks discharge and ignition site.
7. Any permit for a public fireworks display issued by the City may be immediately revoked at any time deemed necessary by the Fire Chief or designee due to any noncompliance, or unsafe weather conditions such as extremely low humidity or wind factor. The display may also be canceled due to accidental ignition of any combustible material in the vicinity of the display.
9.18.200 Cost of Extinguishment. Any person responsible for starting a fire with fireworks shall be liable to the public entities suppressing any such fire for the actual costs of the fire suppression services provided.
9.18.210 Compliance with State Law. This Chapter is intended to implement RCW Chapter 70.77 and WAC 212-17 (as written now or hereafter amended), and shall be construed in connection with those laws and any and all rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto. (Ord 14-04, 2014)
9.18.220 Enforcement. The Fire Chief, or designee, City Code Compliance Officer, and City Police Department are authorized to enforce all provisions of this Chapter and, in addition to criminal sanctions or civil remedies, may revoke any permit issued pursuant to this Chapter upon any failure or refusal of the permittee to comply with the orders and directives of the Fire Chief or designee, City Code Compliance Officer, or City Police Department, and/or to comply with any provisions of this Chapter.
(Ord 14-04, 2014)

Chapter 9.22
WEAPONS ON PREMISES DISPENSING
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
Sections:
9.22.020 Knives.
9.22.030 Unlawful acts.
9.22.040 Exceptions.
9.22.050 Violation--Penalty.
9.22.020 Knives. It is unlawful for any person to carry in any manner whatsoever any knife or other cutting or stabbing instrument with a blade of a length of four or more inches on or in any premises in the city where alcoholic beverages are dispensed by the drink, whether the weapon is concealed or not. (Ord. 1041 '2, 1981).
9.22.030 Unlawful acts. It is unlawful for any person to exhibit, display or draw any firearm, dagger, sword, knife or cutting or stabbing instrument, club or any other weapon apparently capable of producing bodily harm or in any premises in the city where alcoholic beverages are dispensed by the drink. (Ord. 1041 '3, 1981).
9.22.040 Exceptions. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following:
(1) Any lawful act done by a person while in his place of abode or fixed place of business;
(2) Any person, who by virtue of his office, position or employment is vested by law with a duty to preserve public safety, order, or to make arrests for offenses, while carrying out such duties;
(3) Any person making or assisting in making a lawful arrest for the commission of a felony. (Ord. 1041 '4, 1981).
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 20
9.22.050 Violation--Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a term not to exceed sixty days in jail, or by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars, or by both such jail term and fine; and the weapons involved may be permanently confiscated by the city. (Ord. 1041 '5, 1981).
(Ord 12-17, 2012)
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 21
Chapter 9.32
VEGETATION
Sections:
9.32.010 Obstructing streets prohibited.
9.32.020 Menace to public health, safety prohibited.
9.32.030 Growths deemed hazardous.
9.32.040 Removal notice.
9.32.050 Removal by city.
9.32.060 Cost of removal by city, lien notice.
9.32.070 Lien foreclosure.
9.32.080 Recovery of lien costs.
9.32.010 Obstructing streets prohibited. It is unlawful for the owner or occupier of any property within the corporate limits of the city; to allow or permit any tree, tree branch, plants, weeds, shrubs, bushes or vegetation to overhang any sidewalk, street, or alley that obstructs or impairs the free and full use of the sidewalk, alley or street. This prohibition shall be enforced as a public nuisance under the provisions of Chapter 6.30.(Ord. 345 '1, 1951) (Ord 93-43, 1993).
9.32.020 Menace to public health, safety prohibited. It is unlawful for any owner or person occupying any property within the limits of the city; to grow or permit the growth of any grass, weed, or vegetation upon property within the city limits, that constitutes a fire hazard, or a menace to the public health or safety of the people of the city. (Ord. 345 '2, 1951).
9.32.030 Growths deemed hazardous. Any growth of grass, other than lawns, vegetation or weeds upon any of the property within the city limits, which has become dry enough to burn, or may become dry enough to burn, or which may spread by seeds or roots, or contains pollen, or may be carried by the wind; is declared to be a fire hazard, and a menace to the public health and safety. (Ord. 345 '3, 1951).
9.32.040 Removal notice. For the purposes of enforcing sections .020 and .030 all persons who own, or occupy any property within the city, shall immediately after the posting of a notice upon the property for a period of fourteen days, which is signed by the Utility Officer, destroy and remove from the property, all weeds, grass and vegetation. (Ord. 345 '4, 1951) (Ord 93-43, 1993)(Ord. 95-26, 1995).
9.32.050 Removal by city. Whenever any owner or occupant of any property within the city limits, fails, neglects or refuses to remove any weeds, grasses, other than lawns, or vegetation, from his property, after the service for fourteen days of a
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 22
notice describing the property involved, and the hazardous condition; and a demand that the owner remove or destroy the hazardous condition; which notice may be served personally, or posted upon the property, and a copy mailed to the owner at the last known owner' s address in the office of the county treasurer; the city may remove the hazardous condition or destroy it upon the property. (Ord. 345 '6, 1951) (Ord 93-43, 1993).
9.32.060 Cost of removal by city, lien notice. An account of the actual cost for removal or destruction of the hazardous condition shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. The clerk shall prepare and file with the county auditor, a notice of a lien in substantially the form prescribed by RCW Chapter 60.04; and filed within the time prescribed. (Ord. 345 '7, 1951) (Ord 93-43, 1993).
9.32.070 Lien foreclosure. At any time after filing the notice and within eight months thereafter the city on behalf of the city, shall commence proceedings to foreclose the lien, and proceed to sell the property in the manner and in accordance with the laws relating to foreclosure and sale of property for labor and mechanics liens; which statutes are referred to and made a part of this chapter as if fully set out herein. (Ord. 345 '8, 1951).
9.32.080 Recovery of lien costs. In addition to the cost of removal or destruction of the hazardous condition, the city shall be entitled to recover the cost of filing the notice of lien, all court costs and a reasonable attorney's fee to be fixed by the court; and all of which shall be a part of the lien foreclosure and sale of the property. All of which lien laws, foreclosure and sale of property are adopted in to. (Ord. 345 '9, 1951).
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 23
Chapter 9.36
DISCHARGE OF WATER
Sections:
9.36.010 Air conditioner runoff regulations.
9.36.020 Roof runoff regulations.
9.36.010 Air conditioner runoff regulations. Every person who shall have, or permit another to have upon any commercial building under his control an air conditioning or cooling apparatus or device upon any building which employs the use of water in connection therewith, shall make provision that the water used therein shall drain or run into the sanitary or storm sewer system of the city in such manner that the water shall not be allowed to run or fall upon the street, sidewalks or ground surface of the town except through downspouts and drains under the sidewalks to the curb and that such persons shall not be permitted or permit any other person to lay any pipes, hose or other device across or upon any sidewalk or street for the purpose of carrying away the water, and that the commission of any of the acts prohibited by this chapter is declared to be a public nuisance and against the public health. (Ord. 258 Art. 1, 1948).
9.36.020 Roof runoff regulations. No water shall be permitted to run or drain from the roof, marquee, or other part of any building in the city so that the same shall run or fall upon any street, sidewalk or alley of the city, and the owner of any building or the tenant in possession of it shall make proper arrangements for the running or draining of the water into the storm sewers of the city. Water to be released into the storm sewer system shall be drained into a downspout which will conduct the water under the sidewalk to the curbs. All drainage pipe installed under the sidewalk shall be inspected and approved by the city engineer. The owner of the premises shall be responsible for keeping all drains in good working order, and the permitting of any water from the roof, marquee, or other part of any building in the city to run or fall upon any street sidewalk or alley in the city except through downspouts and drains to the curb is declared to be a public nuisance and against the public health. Violation of any provision of this section will subject the owner of the property to a C-9 Penalty. Upon the first notification by the City, the owner of property not properly conducting runoff to the City storm water system shall have thirty (30) days to correct the violation. Following the first notification period by the City, continued violations will result in additional C-9 penalties to the property owner for every occurrence thereafter. (Ord. 296 '1, 1950: Ord. 258 Art. 2, 1948; Ord. 06-28, 2006).
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 24
Chapter 9.40
PARK RULES AND REGULATIONS
Sections:
9.40.010 Purpose
9.40.020 Identification of Parks
9.40.030 Hours of Operation
9.40.040 Prohibited Acts
9.40.050 Violations-Penalty
9.40.010 Purpose. The establishment and maintenance of park property and facilities is intended to benefit current and future citizens of the City of Ephrata by providing opportunities for active and passive recreation. Rules and regulations governing use of park properties and park facilities will help to ensure that park property and park facilities are used and maintained in a beneficial manner to the community. The foregoing park rules and regulations are intended to provide standards for the public use and enjoyment of these facilities and to provide for the public health, safety, welfare and protection in the use and enjoyment of these facilities.
9.40.020 Identification of Parks. Parks are identified as any existing or future city parks, presently including Lee, Ephrata Sports Complex (including the Splashzone and Skate Park), Lions, Ephrata Cemetery, Patrick, and Sun Basin Plaza.
9.40.030 Hours of operation. Parks shall be open to the public from 6:00a.m. to 10:00p.m.. No person shall enter or remain in any municipal park for any purpose whatsoever between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m. Activities on park property or in park facilities that exceed normal hours of operation may be authorized in association with a lease agreement or park use permit authorized by the city council.
9.40.040 Prohibited acts.
A. All activities that constitute civil or criminal violations under state, local or federal statutes shall be prohibited on park property or in park facilities.
B. It is unlawful for any person to do or permit any of the following acts within any city park:
1. Scatter, leave, throw, break or strew any litter, bottles, glass, paper, debris, garbage, refuse, or advertising matter in any park except in designated receptacles; provided, however, that it is further unlawful to deposit in such designated litter receptacles or elsewhere within a park any refuse, litter or other trash collected at the home, business or other dwelling of any person and intentionally brought to the park solely for the purpose of disposing of such refuse, litter or trash.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 25
2. Damage, deface, mar, or destroy any park equipment or facility.
3. Cut, damage or destroy any park trees, shrubs, landscaping or plants, including grass.
4. Consume any beer, wine or intoxicating liquor in any park, or have possession of any container of beer, wine or intoxicating liquor in any park.
5. Drive or park any vehicle on the grass in any park or any other place not specifically designated for vehicular traffic, or operate a vehicle negligently within any park or park facility.
6. Disturb or molest the peace of others using the park and park facilities.
7. Solicit, promote or engage in any private commercial enterprise without prior approval of the city council.
8. Start or maintain a fire except in permanent park facilities provided for that purpose or in a barbeque, hibachi or other freestanding apparatus commonly used for outdoor food preparation purposes.
9. Camp in any portion of any park.
10. Bring, ride, leave, turn loose, or allow any animal to be within a park or park facility, other than a dog under positive control.
11. Erect, put or place any sign or advertisement in a park or park facility.
12. Engage or participate in any disorderly, lewd, obscene, drunken, or indecent conduct within any park or park facility.
13. Use or engage in any of the following activities: archery, discus, javelin, shot, golf, or aircraft, rocket or missile powered devices unless specific permission is obtained from the City Council or City Administration.
(Ord. 09-08, 2009)
9.40.050 Violations - Penalty. Any violation of any provision of this Chapter shall constitute a civil infraction. Each violation of any provision of this Chapter shall constitute a separate offense and the violator shall be subject to a C-9 monetary penalty as provided in EMC 1.04.030. (Ord. 03-21, 2003)
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 26
Chapter 9.48
FISHING IN OASIS PARK
Sections:
9.48.010 Permitted when.
9.48.020 Persons allowed fishing rights.
9.48.040 Assistance and attendance regulations.
9.48.050 Penalty for violations.
9.48.010 Permitted when. Fishing in all waters located in the Oasis Park owned by the city of Ephrata shall be permitted during daylight hours only. Beginning and ending from the third (3rd) Saturday in April to Labor Day both days inclusive each year. (Ord. 91-25, 1991)
9.48.020 Persons allowed fishing rights. Only persons of the age of fourteen (14) years and under and an individual who has an impairment, including a mobility, sensory or cognitive impairment, which results in a functional limitation shall be allowed to fish in said waters, and the bag limit for each person shall be five (5) of any size fish.
9.48.040 Assistance and attendance regulations. All persons authorized in this chapter to fish in the waters located in Oasis Park shall immediately attend their fishing pole at all times and may be assisted by other adult persons only for the purpose of instruction.
9.48.050 Penalty for violations. Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter is deemed to have committed a civil infraction and shall have a C-7 penalty. (Ord. 91-25, 1991)
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 27
Chapter 9.52
BICYCLES, ROLLER SKATING, SCOOTERS & SKATEBOARDS
Sections:
9.52.010 Definitions
9.52.020 Bicycle Regulation
9.52.030 Adoption by Reference
9.52.040 Prohibited Areas
9.52.050 Control
9.52.060 Traffic Control Devices
9.52.070 Penalty - Impoundment
9.52.010 Definitions. The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall for the purposes of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section.
A. "Roller skates" means a pair of shoes, mounted, permanently or temporarily, upon two sets of wheels or a row of wheels and is most often propelled by the user in an upright, crouched or kneeling position.
B. "Scooter" means a footboard mounted upon two or more wheels and controlled by an upright steering handle. This device is propelled by the user in an essentially upright position.
C. "Skateboard" means a footboard mounted upon four or more wheels and is usually propelled by the user who sometimes stands, sits, kneels or lays upon the device while it is in motion.
D. "To operate in a negligent manner" means the operation of one or more of the above described devices in such a manner as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. Examples of operating in a negligent manner include, but are not limited to, failure to yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and/or vehicular traffic.
E. "Central Business District" means that portion the city defined by the West side of Alder Street and the streets of Third Avenue Southwest, Second Avenue Northwest, and C Street, excepting the West side of C Street Southwest from Third Avenue Southwest to First Avenue Southwest. It shall include the sidewalks of both sides of those streets which define this area. (Ord 93-11; 1993; Ord 95-2)
9.52.020 Bicycle Regulation - Supplementary. The provisions of this chapter are supplementary to the provisions of state law which already govern the operation of bicycles.
9.52.030 Adoption by Reference. The provisions of RCW 46.90.545 - .555 and 46.90.565 are hereby adopted by reference.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 28
9.52.040 Prohibited Areas.
(1) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or ride upon any skateboard, roller skates or scooter upon any street, alley, sidewalk or publicly owned parking lot in the Central Business District of the city as that area is defined in Section .010.
(2) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or ride upon any bicycle upon any sidewalk or publicly owned parking lot in the Central Business District of the city as that area is defined in Section .010.
(3) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or ride upon any bicycle, skateboard, roller skates or scooter upon city owned park, tennis court, parking lot, or any other city owned or controlled property which has been properly posted by the City Administrator or his designee.
9.52.050 Control. No skateboard, roller skates or scooter shall be ridden or operated in a negligent manner but shall be operated with reasonable regard for the safety of the operator and other persons and property.
9.52.060 Traffic Control Devices.
(1) Any person operating a skateboard, roller skates or scooter shall obey the instructions of official traffic control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
(2) Any person operating a skateboard, roller skates or scooter shall obey the instructions control signs installed or placed by the City Administrator or his designee regulating the operation or use of such devices.
9.52.070 Penalty - Impoundment.
(1) Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to have committed a civil infraction and shall be punished by a C-15 penalty for the first offense within a six month period and by a C-13 penalty for a second or subsequent violation within a six month period. The fact one violation may be committed upon a different device than another violation is no defense tot he enhanced penalty.
(2) The chief of police is empowered and authorized to administer the provisions of this chapter. The chief or any of his officers, regular and reserve, or any person designated by the chief for the purpose of enforcement of this chapter is empowered to and shall impound any device operated in violation of this chapter. Any device impounded pursuant to this chapter shall be held by the chief of police for a period of at least 15 days. During that time the chief of police shall investigate to the extent possible to determine if the device is stolen. If the device is not determined to be stolen, it shall be released to a person over the age of eighteen years who shall establish a sufficient relationship to the person from whom the device is impounded to insure the device will be returned to the person from whom it was impounded. Before release from impoundment, the chief of police or his designee shall collect an administrative fee of $20.00 for the handling and storage of the impounded device. (Ord. 91-19, 1991)

PROHIBITING/RESTRICTING THE USE OF CARGO

9.56.035 Restricting Placement of Containers and the Like in C-2 Commercial Zone:
A conditional use permit shall be required for the placement of each cargo container used for permanent or temporary storage within the C-2 zone. The Hearing Examiner may impose conditions for the granting of a conditional use permit, consistent with the intent of this chapter. The following additional restrictions shall apply to placement of a Container within C-2 zone:
1. Containers shall be used only as an accessory to the primary use, such primary use being situated in an adjoining building.
2. Containers shall be placed on a level concrete, asphalt, or other approved surface at all times.
3. Containers shall no be stacked.
4. Fire apparatus access shall be provided to both the containers and to the primary structure in accordance with EMC 16.04.150 Appendix D.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 30
5. Containers shall not be visible to the motoring public or from residential neighborhoods immediately adjacent to the property where it is located unless other measures approved by the Hearing Examiner are employed to mitigate the visual impacts of the containers. However, the Hearing Examiner does not need to require mitigation measures if it determines that the motoring public or adjacent residential neighborhoods are not impacted. (Ord. 12-02, 2012)
6. Containers shall abide by all setback requirements applicable to the zone in which they are located.
7. The recipient of the conditional use permit is the only party allowed to use the Container(s).
8. Containers shall be painted so as to blend in with the building to which they are associated.
9. Containers shall have a maximum allowable square footage of container storage area not to exceed eight percent (8%) of the gross floor area of the building with which the container(s) is/are associated, and not to exceed eight (8) containers total under any circumstances.
10. A cargo container shall not remain on site if, the use it is accessory to, is abandoned or changes use, unless a separate conditional use permit is granted.
11. When located in special flood hazard areas, the cargo container shall be securely anchored to prevent flotation.
12. Cargo containers shall not be used for rental and/or mini-storage purposes.
(Ord. 12-02, 2012)

EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 31
CHAPTER 9.60
GRAFFITI ABATEMENT CODE
Sections:
9.60.010 Statement of purpose
9.60.020 Definitions
9.60.030 Graffiti prohibited
9.60.040 Failure to remove graffiti prohibited
9.60.050 Continued presence of graffiti an infraction
9.60.060 Graffiti – Notice of removal
9.60.070 Appeal
9.60.080 Violation
9.60.090 Severability
9.60.010 Statement of purpose. Because existing graffiti will attract and create more graffiti, graffiti is a blight on the aesthetic beauty of Ephrata, and graffiti is connected to gang activity; the City Council for the City of Ephrata has determined that graffiti is a public nuisance. Therefore there is a need for an ordinance prohibiting graffiti and which requires regulating the cleanup of graffiti within the city limits of Ephrata. After considering the matter and having heard input from staff and citizens, the City Council adopts the ordinance codified in this chapter as necessary for the general benefit, health, and welfare of the residents of the City of Ephrata.
9.60.020 Definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the following meanings:
(1) “Abate” means the removal, painting over, or other obscuring of graffiti from view as directed by the notice provided for in EMC 9.60.040 and 9.60.060.
(2) “Graffiti” means the defacing, damaging or destroying by spraying of paint or marking of ink, chalk, dye or other similar substances on public or private buildings, structures, facilities, natural features, and places.
(3) “Graffiti nuisance property” means property upon which graffiti exists and where, after notice as provided by this chapter, the graffiti has not been abated by the deadline set in a notice as established by this chapter.
(4) “Graffiti abatement procedure” means the abatement process; which identifies graffiti, issues notice to the property owner to abate the graffiti, and cures in absence of response.
(5) “Owner” means any person or persons, entity or entities, corporations or other associations having a legal or equitable interest in real or personal property
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 32
including but not limited to the interest of a tenant or lessee.
(6) “Responsible party” means an owner, and also an entity or person acting as an agent for an owner, or an entity or a person who has dominion and control over a property. There may be more than one responsible party for a particular property.
9.60.030 Graffiti prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to spray, write, paint, disfigure, or draw an inscription, figure, or mark upon a building, fence, gate, sign, bridge, or other structure, tree or rock, regardless of being either publicly or privately owned.
9.60.040 Failure to remove graffiti prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any real property in the city of Ephrata, Washington, to permit any graffiti to remain on their property more than 10-days after receipt of a notice to abate, providing seasonal temperatures and weather conditions permit the painting of exterior surfaces. If seasonal temperatures and weather conditions do not allow for the painting of exterior surfaces within the 10-day period, owner shall make arrangements with the Code Enforcement Official, or one of their representatives, to extend the 10-day period. Said arrangements shall be in writing, signed by both owner and the Code Enforcement Official or one of their representatives. Said arrangements shall include a reasonable alternative for temporarily covering or obscuring the graffiti until painting is permitted.
9.60.050 Continued presence of graffiti an infraction. It shall be a civil infraction for a responsible party to allow a graffiti-nuisance property to exist. Each day a graffiti nuisance property shall exist shall be a separate infraction. A civil infraction under this chapter shall be punishable by a penalty as provided for in section 9.60.080 for each violation.
9.60.060 Graffiti– Notice of removal. (1) Procedure. It shall be the duty of the Code Enforcement Official or one of their representatives, or the mayor’s designee, to notify such person or persons violating any provision of this chapter to abate such nuisance within 10-days after receipt of a notice to abate graffiti. Said notice to abate graffiti shall be sent by certified mail/return receipt requested to the last known address of the responsible party and to the address of the party, or personally served. In the event an owner fails to remove the graffiti within the 10-day period or fails to make arrangements to extend the 10-day period if seasonal temperatures and weather conditions do not permit the painting of exterior surfaces, the Code Enforcement Official may issue a civil infraction for each day that the nuisance exists.
(2) All penalties and fines shall be assessed to the violator of this chapter and collected in a civil action. The city may take all lawful action to collect the debt of the responsible party or to foreclose any lien upon the graffiti nuisance property.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 9 - 33
(3) Payment of a monetary penalty pursuant to this chapter does not relieve the responsible party of the duty to abate the graffiti nuisance. The monetary penalty constitutes a personal obligation of the responsible party to whom the notice of civil violation is issued. Any monetary penalty imposed pursuant to this chapter shall accrue interest from the date payment is due at the maximum rate authorized by law for interest on civil judgments, and there shall be added to such penalty the reasonable attorney’s fees and costs incurred in collecting it.
9.60.070 Appeal. Owner may, within 10-days after receipt of the notice to abate graffiti, file a written notice of appeal with the City Clerk. Filing of an appeal will stay any enforcement or actions by the city to abate the graffiti nuisance. The appeal shall be to the hearing examiner, pursuant to EMC 19.06.010. The hearing examiner shall determine whether (1) graffiti exists upon property within the City of Ephrata in violation of this chapter; (2) whether proper notice has been given to the appropriate person; and (3) whether the time for abatement is reasonable in light of seasonal temperatures and weather conditions. If no appeal is filed within said 10-days, the “Notice of Graffiti, of Graffiti Nuisance Property and Removal” shall become final and conclusive, and not subject to appeal or review in any forum.
The hearing examiner’s decision becomes final 21-days after the date of the decision unless the decision of the hearing examiner is appealed to the Grant County Superior Court.
9.60.080 Violation. Any person found to be in violation of EMC 9.60.030 of this chapter shall be deemed to have committed a civil infraction and for each violation shall be subject to a C-1 civil penalty pursuant to EMC 1.04.030. Any person found to be in violation of any other provision of this chapter shall be deemed to have committed a civil infraction and for each violation shall be subject to a C-12 civil penalty pursuant to EMC 1.40.030.
9.60.90 Severability. The provisions of this chapter are declared to be separate and severable. If any clause, sentence, paragraph, subdivision, section, subsection or portion of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person or circumstance, is held to be invalid, it shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this chapter, or the validity of its application to other persons or circumstances.
(Ord. 08-07, 2008)

EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 10 - 2
Chapter 10.10
MOTORIZED SCOOTERS
Sections:
10.10.010 Statutory authority.
10.10.020 Definition.
10.10.030 Rules of operation.
10.10.040 Responsibility.
10.10.050 Violation - penalty.
10.10.060 Confiscation.
10.10.010 Statutory authority. The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed an exercise of the authority and power of the city to regulate the use of motorized scooters as allowed by RCW 46.61.710, for the purposes of enhancing the health, safety, and welfare of its citizens and to promote the orderly flow of traffic in the City of Ephrata.
10.10.020 Definition of motorized foot scooter. A device with no more than two ten-inch or smaller diameter wheels that has handlebars, is designed to be stood or sat upon by the operator, and is powered by an internal combustion engine or electric motor that is capable of propelling the device with or without human propulsion.
Definition of Pocket Bike/Pocket Rocket/Mini-Motorcycle. Any motor driven device that meets the definition of motorcycle set forth in RCW 46.04.330 as a motor vehicle designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, on which the driver rides astride the motor unit or power train and is designed to be steered with a handle bar, but does not meet one or more of the requirements for operation on roadways set forth in RCW 46.37.525, RCW 46.37.400, and RCW 46.37.420.
10.10.030 Rules of operation.
A. Motorized foot scooters shall not be operated on public roadways with a speed limit of greater than 25 miles per hour.
B. Operators of motorized foot scooters shall adhere to all rules of the road applicable to motorized vehicles, pedestrians and bicycles, as well as instructions of official traffic control signals, signs, and other control devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
C. Motorized foot scooters shall not be operated on City owned property, City parks, walkways, paths, trails, sidewalks or any other place where other motorized vehicles are expressly prohibited.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 10 - 3
D. Motorized foot scooters shall not be operated on publicly owned parking lots, and privately owned parking lots without the permission of the owner.
E. Motorized foot scooters shall not be operated at any time during one half hour after sunset to one half hour before sunrise unless equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type approved by the state patrol which shall be visible from all distances up to six hundred feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful low beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of five hundred feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. A light emitting diode flashing taillight visible from a distance of five hundred feet to the rear may also be used in addition to the red reflector.
F. No person shall transport or tow another person on, in or with a motorized foot scooter within the City of Ephrata.
G. Motorized foot scooters shall not be ridden in a negligent or unsafe manner, but shall be operated with reasonable regard for the safety of the operator, and other persons, and in a manner to avoid damage to real or personal property. For purposes of this section, to operate “in a negligent or unsafe manner” means operation of a vehicle in such a manner as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property.
H. Motorized foot scooters shall not be operated without an approved helmet designed for safety which shall have either the neck or chin strap fastened securely while the motorized foot scooter is in motion. “Helmet” means a protective covering for the head consisting of a hard outer shell, padding adjacent to and inside the outer shell and a neck or chin strap type retention system, with a label required by the Federal Consumer Product Safety Committee as adopted by the Code of Federal Regulations 16 CFR 12.03, or an approved safety design that meets or exceeds the requirements of standard Z.90.4 set by American National Standard Institute, or a subsequently nationally recognized standard for helmet performance as the city may adopt.
I. Motorized foot scooters must be equipped with a braking device which forces a wheel to skid on clean, dry, level pavement.
J. Operation of a motorized foot scooter is subject to the provisions of the City of Ephrata noise ordinance. Operation of a gas motorized foot scooter without a muffling device, or operation with a modified muffling device is unlawful.
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 10 - 4
K. Operation of “Pocket Bikes/Pocket Rockets/Mini-Motorcycles” are banned from operation on any public right of way, City owned property, City parks, walkways, paths, trails, sidewalks or any other place where other motorized vehicles are expressly prohibited, or on publicly owned parking lots, and privately owned parking lots without the permission of the owner.
10.10.040 Responsibility. No person shall do any act forbidden by this chapter or fail to perform any act required by this chapter. The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter.
10.10.050 Violation-penalty. Any person violating this chapter shall be guilty of a civil infraction and shall be punished by imposition of a monetary penalty as follows:
Operation in a negligent manner or in a restricted area: C-12
First violation of any other provision: C-9
Second violation of any provision: C-6
Third or subsequent violation of any provision: C-6 and confiscation
10.10.060 Confiscation. In the event of a third or subsequent offense, the motorized foot scooter may be seized and held for a 90-day period by the Ephrata Police Department. After 90 days, the scooter may be released to the owner, upon verification of ownership satisfactory to the Police Department, and upon payment of a $50.00 administrative processing fee to the City of Ephrata. Any unclaimed motorized foot scooters may be disposed of in accordance with state law.
(Ord. 05-08, 2005)
EPHRATA MUNICIPAL CODE 10 - 5
Chapter 10.16
SPEED REGULATIONS
Sections:
10.16.010 State speed laws applicable.
10.16.020 Decrease of state speed limit at certain intersections.
10.16.030 Increasing speed limit in certain zones.

10.16.010 State speed laws applicable.
